Task-Load-Aware Game-Theoretic Framework for Wireless Federated Learning

Jiawei Liu, Guopeng Zhang, Kezhi Wang, and Kun Yang Jiawei Liu and Guopeng Zhang are with the School of Computer Science and Technology, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou 221116, China (e-mail: jwliu@cumt.edu.cn; gpzhang@cumt.edu.cn).Kezhi Wang is with the Department of Computer and Information Science, Northumbria University, Newcastle NE1 8ST, U.K. (e-mail: kezhi.wang@northumbria.ac.uk).Kun Yang is with the School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering, University of Essex, Colchester CO4 3SQ, U.K. (e-mail: kunyang@essex.ac.uk).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) can protect data privacy but has difficulties in motivating user equipment (UE) to engage in task training. This paper proposes a Bertrand-game based framework to address the incentive problem, where a model owner (MO) issues an FL task and the employed UEs help train the model by using their local data. Specially, we consider the impact of time-varying task load and channel quality on UE’s motivation to engage in the FL task. We adopt the finite-state discrete-time Markov chain (FSDT-MC) to predict these parameters during the FL task. Depending on the performance metrics set by the MO and the estimated energy cost of the FL task, each UE seeks to maximize its profit. We obtain the Nash equilibrium (NE) of the game in closed form, and develop a distributed iterative algorithm to find it. Finally, simulation result verifies the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

Index Terms:
Machine learning, federated learning, resource allocation, Bertrand game, Nash equilibrium.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1] is a distributed machine learning (ML) framework that allows multiple clients to collaboratively train an ML model without exposing their raw data. In FL framework, a model owner (MO) first sends a global model to edge or mobile clients. Then the clients can train the model with their local data and transmit the updated model parameters to the MO for a new aggregated model. This process iterates until the required accuracy is achieved.

Although FL protects data privacy, it causes additional energy cost of clients for model training and parameter transmission, thus limiting their motivation to engage in FL [2]. To address this issue, a Stackelberg game is proposed in [3] to encourage clients to reduce the completion time of FL tasks. In [4], a reinforcement learning-based incentive mechanism is designed to find the optimal pricing and training strategies for the clients. In [5], a Stackelberg game is proposed to motivate the MO and clients to build a high-quality FL model. However, several strong assumptions were made in the above works, e.g., the clients have invariant task loads and channel quality during an FL task. These assumptions apply only to situations where the clients are computationally powerful edge servers connected with the wired networks. When the clients are mobile UEs, the energy and computation power are normally limited, thus the influence of time-varying task load and channel quality on their motivation to engage in FL may be considered.

Against the above background, this paper proposes a Bertrand-game[6] based framework to motivate UEs to engage in FL [7] [8], which considers the changes of task load and channel quality of UEs during an FL task. Firstly, given the performance metrics set by the MO, we show that the energy cost of a UE depends not only on the FL-task load but also on its existing-task load. We characterize the dynamic of user’s future task load as an FSDT-MC [9]. Then, the energy cost of a UE caused by multiple rounds of local training can be predicted. Furthermore, we employ another FSDT-MC to describe the channel fading between a UE and the MO, as it has been widely used to simulate Rayleigh fading channels [10]. Then, the energy cost of the UE caused by multiple rounds of parameter transmission can also be estimated. Depending on the predicted overall energy cost for model training and parameter transmission, the UEs can charge the MO independently for the resource usage. At the NE of the game, the MO achieves a set of specified performance metrics with the minimum total payment, while each UE seeks the best price to maximize its own profit. The contribution of this paper is as follows:

1) By integrating the FSDT-MC based task load and channel quality prediction method, a Bertrand game is proposed to help motivate UEs to engage in FL based on the estimated overall energy cost.

2) The NE of the game is addressed in closed form, and an effective iterative algorithm is designed to obtain the NE in a distributed manner.

II-A Energy cost for model training

Before engaging in an FL task, each UE k𝑘k may process some existing tasks (termed as EX-tasks in the following analysis) as shown in Fig. 1. We use fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} to represent the CPU frequency of UE k𝑘k to process the EX-task, and assume that fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} remains constant during the local training session t𝑡t (1≤t≤Ig1𝑡superscript𝐼g1\leq t\leq I^{\text{g}}) whose duration is Ttrnsuperscript𝑇trnT^{\text{trn}}. To admit the FL-task, UE k𝑘k requires an additional Ck=ck​|𝒟k|​Iksubscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝐼𝑘C_{k}=c_{k}|\mathcal{D}_{k}|I_{k} CPU cycles during each session t𝑡t, where cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} is the number of CPU cycles required for training per data sample dk,isubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k,i}. Therefore, UE k𝑘k should raise the CPU frequency by fk=Ck/Ttrnsubscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘superscript𝑇trnf_{k}=C_{k}/T^{\text{trn}} Hz in each session to complete the newly carried FL-task. According to [11], the additional energy cost of UE k𝑘k during session t𝑡t is given as

Ek,tF=νk​(fk,tex+fk)2​Ttrn−νk​(fk,tex)2​Ttrn,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Fsubscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exsubscript𝑓𝑘2superscript𝑇trnsubscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡ex2superscript𝑇trnE_{k,t}^{\text{F}}=\nu_{k}\left(f_{k,t}^{\text{ex}}+f_{k}\right)^{2}T^{\text{trn}}-\nu_{k}\left(f_{k,t}^{\text{ex}}\right)^{2}T^{\text{trn}}, (4)

where νksubscript𝜈𝑘\nu_{k} is the effective switched capacitance of the CPU. Let fmaxsuperscript𝑓maxf^{\text{max}} denote the maximum CPU frequency of the UEs. The following constraint should be satisfied.

0<fk,tex+fk≤fmax,∀k∈𝒦,∀t∈𝒯.formulae-sequence0superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exsubscript𝑓𝑘superscript𝑓maxformulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡𝒯0<f_{k,t}^{\text{ex}}+f_{k}\leq f^{\text{max}},\ \forall k\in{\mathcal{K}},\ \forall t\in\mathcal{T}. (5)

From eq. (4), we know that Ek,tFsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡FE_{k,t}^{\text{F}} depends not only on the FL-task load fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} but also on the EX-task load fkexsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘exf_{k}^{\text{ex}}, which causes the UEs to produce the same amount of CPU cycles, i.e., Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} but consume different amount of energy Ek,tFsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡FE_{k,t}^{\text{F}}. It will affect the pricing strategy of the UEs in the game. It is noted that the fluctuation of the task load in the UE over a short period (e.g., a few tens of seconds) has some kind of randomness, but the task loads in the adjacent time periods may have a strong correlation [12]. Next, we propose an FSDT-MC based method [9] to predict the dynamic of fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} during the FL period. Therefore, each UE can estimate its energy cost for model training and set the price for the resource usage.

  1. 1.

    From ref. [12], we know that the workload fluctuation of a machine over a longer period (e.g., a few minutes) has a strong periodicity, while the workload fluctuation over a shorter period (e.g., a few tens of seconds) has a certain randomness, but the workloads in the adjacent time periods have a strong correlation.

  2. 2.

    In this paper, the time spent for a single round of local training is Ttrn=2superscript𝑇trn2T^{\text{trn}}=2s, the time spent for a single round of parameter transmission is Tcom=0.2superscript𝑇com0.2T^{\text{com}}=0.2s, and the total number of local training sessions is Ig=10superscript𝐼g10I^{\text{g}}=10. Therefore, the total time required to complete a federated learning (FL) task is T=Ig​(Ttrn+Tcom)=22𝑇superscript𝐼gsuperscript𝑇trnsuperscript𝑇com22T=I^{\text{g}}(T^{\text{trn}}+T^{\text{com}})=22s.

  3. 3.

    In the proposed game, the UEs must determine the price of the consumed resource during a FL task. In order to capture the short-term dynamic of users’ workload during the task, we set the observation interval and update period of QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} to T=22𝑇22T=22s (as stated in the response to your last question), and QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} can be timely updated by the workload changes collected at runtime.

According to [9], we discretize the value space of fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} (0≤fk,tex≤fmax0superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exsuperscript𝑓max0\leq f_{k,t}^{\text{ex}}\leq f^{\text{max}}) into M𝑀M equal-width bins as F={F1,⋯,FM}Fsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝑀\textbf{F}=\{F_{1},\ \cdots,\ F_{M}\}, where Fm=m−1M−1​fmaxsubscript𝐹𝑚𝑚1𝑀1superscript𝑓maxF_{m}=\frac{m-1}{M-1}f^{\text{max}} (1≤m≤M1𝑚𝑀1\leq m\leq M) represents a state of the FSDT-MC. Any UE k𝑘k can learn and update the state transition probability (STP) matrix QkF=(αm,m′)M×Msuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘Fsubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚superscript𝑚′𝑀𝑀Q_{k}^{\text{F}}=\left(\alpha_{m,m^{\prime}}\right)_{M\times M} every T𝑇T seconds by using the statistical method , where QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} is an M×M𝑀𝑀M\times M matrix and αm,m′subscript𝛼𝑚superscript𝑚′\alpha_{m,m^{\prime}} is the conditional probability of transitioning from state m𝑚m to m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}. To reflect the short-term dynamics of fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} during an FL period, we set the update period of QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} to T=Ig​(Ttrn+Tcom)𝑇superscript𝐼gsuperscript𝑇trnsuperscript𝑇comT=I^{\text{g}}(T^{\text{trn}}+T^{\text{com}}). The method to obtain and update QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} as follows.

  1. 1.

    Define the observation interval or update period of QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} as T=Ig​(Ttrn+Tcom)𝑇superscript𝐼gsuperscript𝑇trnsuperscript𝑇comT=I^{\text{g}}(T^{\text{trn}}+T^{\text{com}}), where Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}} represents the number of local training sessions, and Ttrnsuperscript𝑇trnT^{\text{trn}} (Tcomsuperscript𝑇comT^{\text{com}}) represent the time spent for a single round of local training (parameter transmission). It means that T𝑇T the observation interval or update period of QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} is the total time required to complete a federated learning task.

  2. 2.

    We divide the observation interval T𝑇T into a large number of (e.g., K𝐾K) small time slots with equal length τ=T/K𝜏𝑇𝐾\tau=T/K. We can use the operating system of a UE to monitor and record the workload, i.e. the operating frequency of the CPU in each slot.

  3. 3.

    Let NmTsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑇N_{m}^{T} denote the number of times that the CPU frequency is in state m𝑚m during the observation interval, Nm,iTsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑖𝑇N_{m,i}^{T} the number of times that the CPU frequency changes from state m𝑚m to state i𝑖i during the observation interval. According to the following literature [13], we can use the observed records to obtain the frequency of the change from state m𝑚m to state i𝑖i during the observation interval as

    p^m,i=Nm,iTNmT, 1≤i,m≤M,and​m≠i,formulae-sequencesubscript^𝑝𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑖𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑇formulae-sequence1𝑖formulae-sequence𝑚𝑀and𝑚𝑖\hat{p}_{m,i}=\frac{N_{m,i}^{T}}{N_{m}^{T}},\ 1\leq i,m\leq M,\ \text{and}\ m\neq i,

    Then, we can take p^m,isubscript^𝑝𝑚𝑖\hat{p}_{m,i} as the probability of the change from state m𝑚m to state i𝑖i during the observation interval, that is

    αm,i=p^m,i=Nm,iTNmT, 1≤i,m≤M,and​m≠i.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑚𝑖subscript^𝑝𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑖𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑚𝑇formulae-sequence1𝑖formulae-sequence𝑚𝑀and𝑚𝑖\alpha_{m,i}=\hat{p}_{m,i}=\frac{N_{m,i}^{T}}{N_{m}^{T}},\ 1\leq i,m\leq M,\ \text{and}\ m\neq i.
  4. 4.

    According to the principle of Markov chain, i.e. the next state of transition only depends on the current state and is independent on the previous states, the transition matrix QkFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} of UE k𝑘k during local training session t𝑡t is constructed as

    QkF=(αm,i)M×M, 1≤i,m≤M,and​m≠i.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘Fsubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑖𝑀𝑀formulae-sequence1𝑖formulae-sequence𝑚𝑀and𝑚𝑖Q_{k}^{\text{F}}=\left(\alpha_{m,i}\right)_{M\times M},\ 1\leq i,m\leq M,\ \text{and}\ m\neq i.

Suppose that fk,t−1exsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡1exf_{k,t-1}^{\text{ex}} is in state m𝑚m during session (t−1)𝑡1(t-1). UE k𝑘k can predict that fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} is in state mtsubscript𝑚𝑡m_{t} during session t𝑡t by extracting the most probable future state m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} (i.e., the one with the largest STP) from QkFsubscriptsuperscript𝑄F𝑘Q^{\text{F}}_{k} at row m𝑚m, which is

mt=arg⁡max∀m′∈{1,⋯,M}αm,m′,∀t∈𝒯.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚𝑡subscriptfor-allsuperscript𝑚′1⋯𝑀subscript𝛼𝑚superscript𝑚′for-all𝑡𝒯\textstyle m_{t}=\mathop{\arg\max}\limits_{\forall m^{\prime}\in\{1,\cdots,M\}}\alpha_{m,m^{\prime}},\ \forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}. (6)

By substituting eq. (6) into eq. (4), UE k𝑘k can estimate its energy cost in training session t𝑡t as

E~k,tF=νk​(Fmt+fk)2​Ttrn−νk​(Fmt)2​Ttrn,∀t∈𝒯.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡Fsubscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑓𝑘2superscript𝑇trnsubscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝑚𝑡2superscript𝑇trnfor-all𝑡𝒯\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}=\nu_{k}\left(F_{m_{t}}+f_{k}\right)^{2}T^{\text{trn}}-\nu_{k}\left(F_{m_{t}}\right)^{2}T^{\text{trn}},\ \forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}. II-B Energy cost for parameter transmission

After each round of local training, the MO assigns UE k𝑘k a time period Tcomsuperscript𝑇comT^{\text{com}} and an orthogonal channel of W𝑊W Hz to upload the updated model parameter wksubscriptw𝑘\textbf{w}_{k}. Let L𝐿L denote the size of wksubscriptw𝑘\textbf{w}_{k}, pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} the transmit power of UE k𝑘k, and gk,tsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡g_{k,t} the channel gain from UE k𝑘k to the MO during the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\text{th}} parameter transmission. Then, the achievable data rate of UE k𝑘k under a given bit error rate (BER) level can be approximated as

rk,t=W​log2⁡(1+Δ​pk,t​gk,t/σ2),subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡𝑊subscript21Δsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑔𝑘𝑡superscript𝜎2r_{k,t}=W\log_{2}\left(1+{\Delta p_{k,t}g_{k,t}}/\sigma^{2}\right), (8)

where σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is noise power and Δ=1.5−ln⁡(5​BER)Δ1.55BER\Delta=\frac{1.5}{-\ln(5\text{BER})} is a constant related to BER. Since rk,t​Tcom≥Lsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡superscript𝑇com𝐿r_{k,t}T^{\text{com}}\geq L should be satisfied, the minimum transmit power of UE k𝑘k is derived as

pk,t=(2LW​Tcom−1)​σ2/(gk,t​Δ).subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡superscript2𝐿𝑊superscript𝑇com1superscript𝜎2subscript𝑔𝑘𝑡Δp_{k,t}=\left(2^{\frac{L}{WT^{\text{com}}}}-1\right){\sigma^{2}}/(g_{k,t}\Delta). (9)

and the resultant energy cost of UE k𝑘k is

Ek,tC=pk,t​Tcom=(2LW​Tcom−1)​σ2​Tcom/(gk,t​Δ).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Csubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡superscript𝑇comsuperscript2𝐿𝑊superscript𝑇com1superscript𝜎2superscript𝑇comsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡Δ\displaystyle E_{k,t}^{\text{C}}=p_{k,t}T^{\text{com}}=\left(2^{\frac{L}{WT^{\text{com}}}}-1\right){\sigma^{2}}T^{\text{com}}/(g_{k,t}\Delta). (10)

Next, we construct an FSDT-MC [10] to predict gk,tsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡g_{k,t} (∀t∈𝒯for-all𝑡𝒯\forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}) for the UEs to develop pricing strategies.

Let Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} denote the channel correlation time, over which the channel response is invariant. For instance, when the system operates on the 900 MHz of 4G (wavelength λ=0.34𝜆0.34\lambda=0.34 m) and the UEs move slowly (speed v≈2𝑣2v\approx 2 m/s), Tc=λv≈0.2subscript𝑇𝑐𝜆𝑣0.2T_{c}=\frac{\lambda}{v}\approx 0.2s [10]. We set Tcom=Tcsuperscript𝑇comsubscript𝑇𝑐T^{\text{com}}=T_{c} and Ttrn=δ​Tcsuperscript𝑇trn𝛿subscript𝑇𝑐T^{\text{trn}}=\delta T_{c}, where δ≫1much-greater-than𝛿1\delta\gg 1 is a positive integer. Divide the time horizon of the system into time slots with equal length Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} and index the slots by τ𝜏\tau. Then, gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} is exponentially distributed over τ𝜏\tau. We represent the lower and upper bounds of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} by gˇˇ𝑔\check{g} and g^^𝑔\hat{g}, respectively, and can then discretize the value space of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} into N𝑁N equal-width levels as L={L1,⋯,LN}Lsubscript𝐿1⋯subscript𝐿𝑁\textbf{L}=\{L_{1},\ \cdots,\ L_{N}\}, where Ln=n−1N−1​(g^−gˇ)subscript𝐿𝑛𝑛1𝑁1^𝑔ˇ𝑔L_{n}=\frac{n-1}{N-1}(\hat{g}-\check{g}), 1≤n≤N1𝑛𝑁1\leq n\leq N, represents a state of the FSDT-MC [10].

Define the STP matrix of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} over τ𝜏\tau as QC=(βn,n′)N×Nsuperscript𝑄Csubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛superscript𝑛′𝑁𝑁Q^{\text{C}}=\left(\beta_{n,n^{\prime}}\right)_{N\times N}, where βn,n′subscript𝛽𝑛superscript𝑛′\beta_{n,n^{\prime}} is the probability that gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} changes from state n𝑛n to n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} as the time goes from τ𝜏\tau to τ+1𝜏1\tau+1. We can obtain QCsuperscript𝑄CQ^{\text{C}} by using the statistical method. The main idea is to take the frequency of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} changing from state n𝑛n to n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} during an observation/update period as the STP βn,n′subscript𝛽𝑛superscript𝑛′\beta_{n,n^{\prime}}. The update period can be adjusted adaptively to reflect the change rate of the channel.

  1. 1.

    Let gˇˇ𝑔\check{g} and g^^𝑔\hat{g} denote the lower and upper bounds of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau}, respectively. We discretize the value of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} into N𝑁N equal-width levels as L={L1,⋯,LN}Lsubscript𝐿1⋯subscript𝐿𝑁\textbf{L}=\{L_{1},\ \cdots,\ L_{N}\}, where

    Ln=n−1N−1​(g^−gˇ),1≤n≤Nformulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑛𝑛1𝑁1^𝑔ˇ𝑔1𝑛𝑁L_{n}=\frac{n-1}{N-1}(\hat{g}-\check{g}),1\leq n\leq N

    represents a state of the FSDT-MC. The state transition of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} over τ𝜏\tau can be described by matrix QC=(βn,j)N×Nsuperscript𝑄Csubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛𝑗𝑁𝑁Q^{\text{C}}=\left(\beta_{n,j}\right)_{N\times N}, where βn,jsubscript𝛽𝑛𝑗\beta_{n,j} is the probability that gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} changes from state n𝑛n to state j𝑗j as the time goes from τ𝜏\tau to τ+1𝜏1\tau+1.

  2. 2.

    Let O=X​τ𝑂𝑋𝜏O=X\tau denote the observation period or update period of QCsuperscript𝑄CQ^{\text{C}}, where X𝑋X is a sufficiently large positive integer. We use Znsubscript𝑍𝑛Z_{n} and Zn,jsubscript𝑍𝑛𝑗Z_{n,j} to represent the numbers of times per observation period that gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} stays in level Lnsubscript𝐿𝑛L_{n} and changes from level Lnsubscript𝐿𝑛L_{n} to level Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}, respectively. Following the priciple of Markov chain, the transition probabilities from state Lnsubscript𝐿𝑛L_{n} to state Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}, i.e., βn,jsubscript𝛽𝑛𝑗\beta_{n,j}, can be approximated by the ratio

    βn,j=Zn,jZn, 1≤n,j≤N,n≠j.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽𝑛𝑗subscript𝑍𝑛𝑗subscript𝑍𝑛formulae-sequence1𝑛formulae-sequence𝑗𝑁𝑛𝑗\beta_{n,j}=\frac{Z_{n,j}}{Z_{n}},\ 1\leq n,j\leq N,\ n\neq j.

    As a result, the transition matrix QC=(βn,j)N×Nsuperscript𝑄Csubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛𝑗𝑁𝑁Q^{\text{C}}=\left(\beta_{n,j}\right)_{N\times N} is obtained.

  3. 3.

    When a user moves not so fast, i.e, the channel state is relatively stable, we can increase the update period of QCsuperscript𝑄CQ^{\text{C}} by increasing X𝑋X. However, when the user moves faster and the channel state changes more dramatically, we can reduce the update period of QCsuperscript𝑄CQ^{\text{C}} by reducing X𝑋X, thus reflecting the rapid change of the channel state. In this paper, we set X=100𝑋100X=100 considering that walking users move at a low speed of 2 m/s.

Assuming that the initial distribution of gk,τ=0subscript𝑔𝑘𝜏0g_{k,\tau=0} over the N𝑁N states is known as π​(gk,τ=0)1×N𝜋subscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏01𝑁\pi(g_{k,\tau=0})_{1\times N}, UE k𝑘k can predict that gk,tsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡g_{k,t} is in state ntsubscript𝑛𝑡n_{t} during the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\text{th}} parameter transmission by extracting the most probable future state n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} from QCsuperscript𝑄CQ^{\text{C}} at row n𝑛n, which is

nt=arg⁡max∀n′∈{1,⋯,N}π​(gk,τ=0)​(QC)t​(TtrnTc+1),∀t∈𝒯.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛𝑡subscriptfor-allsuperscript𝑛′1⋯𝑁𝜋subscript𝑔𝑘𝜏0superscriptsuperscript𝑄C𝑡superscript𝑇trnsubscript𝑇𝑐1for-all𝑡𝒯n_{t}=\mathop{\arg\max}\limits_{\forall n^{\prime}\in\{1,\cdots,N\}}\pi(g_{k,\tau=0})(Q^{\text{C}})^{t(\frac{T^{\text{trn}}}{T_{c}}+1)},\ \forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}. (11)

By substituting eq. (11) into eq. (10), UE k𝑘k can estimate its energy cost for the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\text{th}} parameter transmission as

E~k,tC=(2LW​Tcom−1)​σ2​Tcom/(Lnt​Δ),∀t∈𝒯.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡Csuperscript2𝐿𝑊superscript𝑇com1superscript𝜎2superscript𝑇comsubscript𝐿subscript𝑛𝑡Δfor-all𝑡𝒯\displaystyle\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}}=(2^{\frac{L}{WT^{\text{com}}}}-1){\sigma^{2}}T^{\text{com}}/(L_{n_{t}}\Delta),\ \forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}. where Lntsubscript𝐿subscript𝑛𝑡L_{n_{t}} is the ntthsuperscriptsubscript𝑛𝑡thn_{t}^{\text{th}} state of the FSDT-MC of the channel.

III Game Formulation

To motivate the UEs to engage in FL, an effective way is to enable the UEs to profit from the energy consumption of model training and data uploading. Game theory is a powerful tool to analyze the optimal or equilibrium strategies of the UEs in such a competitive situation. In general, strategic games can be divided into the following two categories [6]: (1) the production-based games, such as Cournot and Stackelberg games, which take the supply quantity of a commodity as a strategy to maximize the players’ profits, and (2) the price-based games, such as Bertrand games, which take the price of a commodity as a strategy to maximize the players’ profits. In the FL system, the UEs have no access to the amount of resources that other UEs contribute, but they can observe the pricing information of others to make decisions. Thus we adopt the Bertrand game to solve the incentive problem. While the UEs fight for market share through price competition, the MO can adjust its purchase according to the prices offered by the UEs, so as to achieve its performance with a minimum total investment. Next, we model the price competition between the UEs and their interaction with the MO as a Bertrand game. The game execution cycle is the time to complete an entire FL task with a continuous Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}}-round global iterations.

  1. 1.

    Strategic games can be divided into the following quantity-based games and price-based games [6].

    1. (a)

      Games based on commodity production, such as Cournot games and Stackelberg games, in which competing monopolists take the supply quantity of a commodity as a strategy to maximize their profits.

    2. (b)

      Games based on commodity price, such as Bertrand games, in which competing monopolists take the price of a commodity as a strategy to maximize their profits.

    In general, the monopolists cannot obtain each other’s production information, but they can easily observe the rivals’ product pricing from the market, which helps the monopolists to make decisions. The price of a commodity is a signal to coordinate the supply and demand of the commodity in the market.

  2. 2.

    In this paper, we motivate the UEs to participate in FL through pricing the consumed resources, and, therefore, the Bertrand game is adopted to solve problem (14).

    1. (a)

      In problem (14), multiple competitive UEs produce homogeneous products (computing and communication resources) and set the prices based on their specific production costs (determined by their respective energy consumption during FL) and others’ prices to meet the market demand (the FL performance ordered by the model server).

    2. (b)

      Similar to the monopolists in a oligopoly market, the UEs have no access to the amount of resources that others contribute to the FL task, but they can obtain the price-information of others to make decisions. Therefore, the proposed game belongs to the price-based games and we adopt the Bertrand game to analyze the incentive problem (14).

1) The objective of UEs: We represent the price asked by UE k𝑘k for training session t𝑡t by ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t} (in Joule/iteration), which is the compensation required by UE k𝑘k for each local iteration over the dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. Denote the overall energy cost of UE k𝑘k for completing a round of local training and parameter transmission by ψk,t=E~k,tF+E~k,tCsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡Fsuperscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡C\psi_{k,t}=\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}+\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}}, and the payment of the MO to UE k𝑘k by ξk,t=ϱk,t​Iksubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐼𝑘\xi_{k,t}=\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}. The aim of UE k𝑘k is to maximize its profit in the total Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}} rounds by choosing the optimal price profile Γk=(ϱk,1,⋯,ϱk,Ig)subscriptΓ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘1⋯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘superscript𝐼g\Gamma_{k}=\left(\varrho_{k,1},\cdots,\varrho_{k,I^{\text{g}}}\right). This can be formulated as the following problem.

maxΓksubscriptsubscriptΓ𝑘\displaystyle\max_{\Gamma_{k}}\; Uk=∑t∈𝒯(ξk,t−ψk,t)=∑t∈𝒯(ϱk,t​Ik−(E~k,tF+E~k,tC))subscript𝑈𝑘subscript𝑡𝒯subscript𝜉𝑘𝑡subscript𝜓𝑘𝑡subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐼𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡Fsuperscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡C\displaystyle U_{k}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}(\xi_{k,t}-\psi_{k,t})=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}(\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}-(\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}+\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}})) (13)
s.t. ϱk,t≥0,∀k∈𝒦,∀t∈𝒯.formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡𝒯\displaystyle\varrho_{k,t}\geq 0,\;\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}},\forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}. (13.1)

2) The objective of the MO: The MO aims to achieve its performance (including the global accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and the training parameters Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}}, Ttrnsuperscript𝑇trnT^{\text{trn}} and Tcomsuperscript𝑇comT^{\text{com}}) with a minimum total investment. Let Θ=(θ1,⋯,θ|𝒦|)Θsubscript𝜃1⋯subscript𝜃𝒦\Theta=\left(\theta_{1},\cdots,\theta_{\left|\mathcal{K}\right|}\right) denote the strategy profile of the MO, which represents the amount of resources it purchases from each UE k𝑘k. Once the UEs determine their optimal prices Γk,∀k∈𝒦subscriptΓ𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\Gamma_{k},\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, the MO can adjust ΘΘ\Theta to achieve its objective, which is formulated as the following problem

minΘsubscriptΘ\displaystyle\min_{\Theta}\; US=∑t∈𝒯∑k∈Kϱk,t​Ik+12​(∑k∈K(θk)2+2​v​∑k≠j(θk​θj)),subscript𝑈Ssubscript𝑡𝒯subscript𝑘𝐾subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐼𝑘12subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘22𝑣subscript𝑘𝑗subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑗\displaystyle U_{\text{S}}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}+\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)}, (14)
s.t. 0<θk≤θmax=1−ζ​log⁡(1ϵ)Ig,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝜃𝑘superscript𝜃max1𝜁1italic-ϵsuperscript𝐼gfor-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle 0<\theta_{k}\leq\theta^{\text{max}}=1-\frac{\zeta\log(\frac{1}{\epsilon})}{I^{\text{g}}},\,\;\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}, (14.1)

where constraint (14.1) indicates the value space of θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}. From eq. (3), we can get θmax=maxk⁡θk=1−ζ​log⁡(1ϵ)Igsuperscript𝜃maxsubscript𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘1𝜁1italic-ϵsuperscript𝐼g\theta^{\text{max}}=\max_{k}\theta_{k}=1-\frac{\zeta\log(\frac{1}{\epsilon})}{I^{\text{g}}}. The meaning of USsubscript𝑈SU_{\text{S}} is given as follows.

  1. 1.

    The meaning of the first term ∑t∈𝒯∑k∈Kϱk,t​Iksubscript𝑡𝒯subscript𝑘𝐾subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐼𝑘\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}.

    1. (a)

      Parameter Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k} represents the required number of local iterations in each kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}} training session to achieve local accuracy θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}.

    2. (b)

      Parameter ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t} represents the price asked by UE k𝑘k for the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\text{th}} training session.

    3. (c)

      Therefore, ∑t∈𝒯∑k∈Kϱk,t​Iksubscript𝑡𝒯subscript𝑘𝐾subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐼𝑘\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}I_{k} represents the total payment of the server to all the UEs in the total Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}} rounds of local training.

  2. 2.

    The second term 12​(∑k∈K(θk)2+2​v​∑k≠j(θk​θj))12subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘22𝑣subscript𝑘𝑗subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑗\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)} considers the Resource Substitutability (RS) in a Bertrand game.

    1. (a)

      We note that the Bertrand game model is first proposed in [14]. The content related to the RS is in the second formula, Part 2, page 547 of ref. [14]. Next, we introduce it briefly.

    2. (b)

      According to ref. [15], the RS is an ability of a buyer to substitute one product (hold by some sellers) with other products (hold by other sellers) of similar functionality. The RS of a buyer is described by parameter v∈[0,1]𝑣01v\in\left[0,1\right]. When v=0𝑣0v=0, there is no substitutability between products sold by different sellers, when v=1𝑣1v=1, the products sold by different sellers are completely homogeneous with each other. Please refer to it for more details.

    3. (c)

      In what follows, we explain how the RS is applied to our game framework for federated learning.

      The function of term 12​(∑k∈K(θk)2+2​v​∑k≠j(θk​θj))12subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘22𝑣subscript𝑘𝑗subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑗\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)} can be explained from the economic aspect, as it tasks the RS into account through parameter v𝑣v.

      It is known that a major challenge to implement FL is to solve the non independent-and-identical distribution of the training data on different UEs. In the considered FL system, the model server faces a limited number of UEs to perform a FL task. If the server needs special datasets owned by certain UEs to train the learning model, the RS of different UEs is weak, namely v𝑣v tends to 0; otherwise, the learning model of the server can be trained on any dataset owned by the UEs, namely, the datasts owned by different UEs have a strong RS, so v𝑣v tends to 1.

    4. (d)

      The issue of statistical heterogeneity of training data is not discussed here as it is beyond the scope of this paper. In the simulation, we set v=0.5𝑣0.5v=0.5 as in [16] to represent a general case. In [16], the authors presented the similar RS-based utility function to address the spectrum allocation problem in multi-user cognitive radio networks. Readers can refer to the first formula in Sec. IV.A, page 4275 of [16] for detail.

IV Solution Of The Game

We first solve problems (13) and (14), respectively, and obtain the NE of the game. Then, an iterative algorithm is developed to find the NE in a distributed manner.

IV-1 Solve the MO problem (14)

In the Bertrand game, each UE k𝑘k first gives the resource price ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k}. Then, the MO can find the optimal resource purchase ΘΘ\Theta according to Γk,∀k∈𝒦subscriptΓ𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\Gamma_{k},\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, by solving problem (14). Through Taylor expansion, one can get −log⁡(1−x)=x+𝒪​(x)1𝑥𝑥𝒪𝑥-\log\left(1-x\right)=x+\mathcal{O}\left(x\right). Then, Eq. (2) can be rewritten as

Ik=−ηk​log⁡(1−(1−θk))=ηk​(1−θk)+𝒪​(1−θk).subscript𝐼𝑘subscript𝜂𝑘11subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜂𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘𝒪1subscript𝜃𝑘I_{k}=-\eta_{k}\log(1-(1-\theta_{k}))=\eta_{k}\left(1-\theta_{k}\right)+\mathcal{O}(1-\theta_{k}). (15)

By substituting eq. (15) into eq. (14), USsubscript𝑈SU_{\text{S}} can be rewritten as

U~S=∑t∈𝒯∑k∈Kϱk,t​ηk​(1−θk)+12​(∑k∈K(θk)2+2​v​∑k≠j(θk​θj)).subscript~𝑈Ssubscript𝑡𝒯subscript𝑘𝐾subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘12subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘22𝑣subscript𝑘𝑗subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑗\displaystyle\tilde{U}_{\text{S}}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}\eta_{k}\left(1-\theta_{k}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)}. (16)

Since U~S​(θk)subscript~𝑈Ssubscript𝜃𝑘\tilde{U}_{\text{S}}(\theta_{k}) is convex with respect to θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}, one can differentiate U~S​(θk)subscript~𝑈Ssubscript𝜃𝑘\tilde{U}_{\text{S}}(\theta_{k}) with respect to θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} and set the results to 0. Then, the optimal solution of problem (14) is obtained as

θk=A​∑t∈𝒯ϱk,t+B​∑j∈𝒦,j≠k∑t∈𝒯ϱj,t,subscript𝜃𝑘𝐴subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡𝐵subscriptformulae-sequence𝑗𝒦𝑗𝑘subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑗𝑡\displaystyle\textstyle\theta_{k}=A\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\varrho_{k,t}+B\sum_{j\in\mathcal{K},j\neq k}\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\varrho_{j,t}, (17)

where A=−(1−2​v+K​v)(1−v)​(K​v+1−v)𝐴12𝑣𝐾𝑣1𝑣𝐾𝑣1𝑣A=\frac{-(1-2v+Kv)}{(1-v)(Kv+1-v)} and B=v(1−v)​(K​v+1−v)𝐵𝑣1𝑣𝐾𝑣1𝑣B=\frac{v}{(1-v)(Kv+1-v)} are constants.

IV-2 Solve the UE problem (13)

After solving problem (14), the resource purchase ΘΘ\Theta of the MO is known. Then, any UE k𝑘k can update its price ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k} by solving problem (13). Note that the pricing of UE k𝑘k for session t𝑡t, i.e., ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t} is affected not only by the accuracy θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} but also by the pricing of the other UEs, which is represented by ϱ−k,t={ϱx,t|∀x∈𝒦​and​x≠k}subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡conditional-setsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑥𝑡for-all𝑥𝒦and𝑥𝑘\varrho_{-k,t}=\{\varrho_{x,t}|\forall x\in\mathcal{K}\ \text{and}\ x\neq k\}. By substituting eq. (17) into problem (13) and expanding it with Taylor. The expression of Uksubscript𝑈𝑘U_{k} can be rewritten as

U~k=∑t∈𝒯Uk,t,subscript~𝑈𝑘subscript𝑡𝒯subscript𝑈𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\textstyle\tilde{U}_{k}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}U_{k,t}, (18)

where Uk,t=ϱk,t​(1+A​∑t∈𝒯ϱk,t−B​V)−Ct​(1+A​∑t∈𝒯ϱk,t−B​V)−(D​(1+A​∑t∈𝒯ϱk,t−B​V)2+E~k,tC)subscript𝑈𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡1𝐴subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡𝐵𝑉subscript𝐶𝑡1𝐴subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡𝐵𝑉𝐷superscript1𝐴subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡𝐵𝑉2superscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡CU_{k,t}=\varrho_{k,t}(1+A\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\varrho_{k,t}-BV)-C_{t}(1+A\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\varrho_{k,t}-BV)-{(D(1+A\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\varrho_{k,t}-BV)^{2}+\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}}}).

As UE k𝑘k can estimate fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} and gk,tsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡g_{k,t} in each session t𝑡t by using eqs. (6) and (11) respectively, the parameters Ct=2​νk​ck​|𝒟k|​fk,texsubscript𝐶𝑡2subscript𝜈𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exC_{t}=2\nu_{k}c_{k}|\mathcal{D}_{k}|f_{k,t}^{\text{ex}}, D=νk​(ck)2​|𝒟k|2Ttrn𝐷subscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘2superscript𝑇trnD=\frac{\nu_{k}(c_{k})^{2}|\mathcal{D}_{k}|^{2}}{T^{\text{trn}}}, V=∑x∈𝒦,x≠k∑t∈𝒯ϱx,t𝑉subscriptformulae-sequence𝑥𝒦𝑥𝑘subscript𝑡𝒯subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑥𝑡V=\sum_{x\in\mathcal{K},x\neq k}\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\varrho_{x,t} and E~k,tCsuperscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡C\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}} in eq. (16) can be treated as constants by UE k𝑘k.

Eq. (18) shows that any UE k𝑘k can decompose the pricing problem into Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}} sub-problems, which can be solved in parallel to get ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t} in each session t𝑡t. Since Uk,t​(ϱk,t)subscript𝑈𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡U_{k,t}(\varrho_{k,t}) given in eq. (18) is concave with respect to ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t}, one can differentiate Uk,t​(ϱk,t)subscript𝑈𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡U_{k,t}(\varrho_{k,t}) with respect to ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t} and set the results to 0. Then, the solution of ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t} is obtained as

ϱk,t=1−A​Ct−B​V−2​A​D+2​A​B​D​V2​A2​D−2​A−∑i∈𝒯,i≠tϱk,i.subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡1𝐴subscript𝐶𝑡𝐵𝑉2𝐴𝐷2𝐴𝐵𝐷𝑉2superscript𝐴2𝐷2𝐴subscriptformulae-sequence𝑖𝒯𝑖𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\textstyle\varrho_{k,t}=\frac{1-AC_{t}-BV-2AD+2ABDV}{2A^{2}D-2A}-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T},i\neq t}\varrho_{k,i}. (19)

IV-3 Find the NE of the game

At the NE of the game, neither the MO nor each of the UEs can get higher profit from changing the strategy profile, i.e., ΘΘ\Theta or ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k}. Denote the NE strategy profile of the MO and the UEs by {Θ^,Γ^1,⋯,Γ^k}^Θsubscript^Γ1⋯subscript^Γ𝑘\{\hat{\Theta},\hat{\Gamma}_{1},\cdots,\hat{\Gamma}_{k}\}, where Θ^=(θ^1,⋯,θ^|𝒦|)^Θsubscript^𝜃1⋯subscript^𝜃𝒦\hat{\Theta}=\left(\hat{\theta}_{1},\cdots,\hat{\theta}_{\left|\mathcal{K}\right|}\right) and Γ^k=(ϱ^k,1,⋯,ϱ^k,Ig)subscript^Γ𝑘subscript^italic-ϱ𝑘1⋯subscript^italic-ϱ𝑘superscript𝐼𝑔\hat{\Gamma}_{k}=\left(\hat{\varrho}_{k,1},\cdots,\hat{\varrho}_{k,I^{g}}\right). We propose an iterative algorithm to find the NE.

Let i=1,2,⋯𝑖12⋯i=1,2,\cdots denote the iteration numbers. In the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} iteration, we use Γk​[i]subscriptΓ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖\Gamma_{k}[i], Γ−k​[i]subscriptΓ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖\Gamma_{-k}[i] and Θ​[i]Θdelimited-[]𝑖\Theta[i] to represent the pricing of UE k𝑘k, the pricing of the UEs in set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} other than UE k𝑘k, and the resource purchase of the MO, respectively. Given that the pricing of all UEs are observable in a market, the following distributed algorithm is designed to find the NE.

Because Uk​(ϱk,t)subscript𝑈𝑘subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡U_{k}(\varrho_{k,t}) is strictly concave with respect to ϱk,tsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘𝑡\varrho_{k,t}, the upper bound on the iteration number of Algorithm 1 to reach the convergence threshold ΞΞ\Xi is 𝒪​(log⁡1Ξ)𝒪1Ξ\mathcal{O}(\log\frac{1}{\Xi}) [17] and the computational complexity of Algorithm 1 is log⁡1Ξ​(K+Ig)1Ξ𝐾superscript𝐼𝑔\log\frac{1}{\Xi}(K+I^{g}) [18]. Although it is assumed that all the UEs are willing to engage in the FL task, some of them cannot be selected because their computing power fails to meet the requirement of local relative accuracy θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}. Then we apply constraint (14.1) to the outcome of Algorithm 1 and determine which UEs are qualified for the FL task. Finally, we give the execution process of the game in the following Algorithm 2, which is termed as the task-load-aware game-theoretic scheme (TLA-GTS)

In Algorithm 2, we initialize 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} as all the potential client UEs for the MO. After performing Algorithm 1, one can make the following choices according to the obtained solution. If the solution satisfies constraint (14.1), the algorithm terminates and the solution is taken as the NE of the game. Otherwise, the UE with the highest price is removed from set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, and Algorithm 1 is performed again until constraint (14.1) is satisfied or set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} is empty. An empty UE set indicates that the performance set by the MO (e.g., ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, Igsuperscript𝐼gI^{\text{g}}, Ttrnsuperscript𝑇trnT^{\text{trn}} and Tcomsuperscript𝑇comT^{\text{com}}) cannot be achieved by the UEs. The MO needs to lower the performance metrics and restart the game. Algorithm 2 is implemented by performing Algorithm 1 for K𝐾K times. Therefore, its computational complexity is log⁡1Ξ​(K2+K​Ig)1Ξsuperscript𝐾2𝐾superscript𝐼𝑔\log\frac{1}{\Xi}(K^{2}+KI^{g}).

V Simulation Results

One MO and four UEs are placed in wireless networks, e.g., WLAN. We set fmax=2superscript𝑓max2f^{\text{max}}=2 GHz[11] and discretize fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} (0≤fk,tex≤fmax0superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exsuperscript𝑓max0\leq f_{k,t}^{\text{ex}}\leq f^{\text{max}}) of each UE k𝑘k into 5 levels. The lower and upper bounds of the time-varying channel gain gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} is set to gˇ=20.4−1ˇ𝑔superscript20.41\check{g}=2^{0.4}-1 and g^=23.1−1^𝑔superscript23.11\hat{g}=2^{3.1}-1[19], respectively, and the transition probability matrix QCsuperscript𝑄CQ^{\text{C}} of gk,τsubscript𝑔𝑘𝜏g_{k,\tau} as follows.

The other simulation parameters include dataset size |𝒟k|=8×107subscript𝒟𝑘8superscript107|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=8\times 10^{7} [11], the number of CPU cycles for computing one data sample ck=15subscript𝑐𝑘15c_{k}=15[11], the size of model parameters L=0.1𝐿0.1L=0.1 Mb, the global iteration number Ig=10superscript𝐼g10I^{\text{g}}=10, the duration for each local training Ttrn=2superscript𝑇trn2T^{\text{trn}}=2s, the duration for each parameter transmission Tcom=0.2superscript𝑇com0.2T^{\text{com}}=0.2s, the CPU parameter νk=10−28subscript𝜈𝑘superscript1028\nu_{k}=10^{-28}[11], the bandwidth allocated to each UE W=1𝑊1W=1 MHz, the noise power σ2=10−9superscript𝜎2superscript109\sigma^{2}=10^{-9}, the BER requirement 10−3superscript10310^{-3}, the substitutability factor for the MO v=0.5𝑣0.5v=0.5, ηk=1subscript𝜂𝑘1\eta_{k}=1 in eq. (2), and ζ=1𝜁1\zeta=1 in eq. (3).

First, we show the impact of different EX-task load fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} on the pricing of the UEs. For that purpose, we set fk,t=0ex=0superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡0ex0f_{k,t=0}^{\text{ex}}=0 for all the 4 UEs. Following eq. (6), fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} of the UEs in 3 consecutive training sessions (e.g., t=1,2,3𝑡123t=1,2,3) are estimated as f1,tex={0,0.5,1.5}superscriptsubscript𝑓1𝑡ex00.51.5f_{1,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{0,0.5,1.5\}, f2,tex={0.5,1,1}superscriptsubscript𝑓2𝑡ex0.511f_{2,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{0.5,1,1\}, f3,tex={1,1.5,1}superscriptsubscript𝑓3𝑡ex11.51f_{3,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{1,1.5,1\}, and f4,tex={1,0,1}superscriptsubscript𝑓4𝑡ex101f_{4,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{1,0,1\}, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the convergence of the prices of the UEs in the 3 training sessions.

As shown in Fig. 2, the UEs with lower fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} have a price advantage over the UEs with higher fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} in each training session. As the energy cost for data uploading Ek,tCsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡CE_{k,t}^{\text{C}} is negligible compared to that for model training Ek,tFsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡FE_{k,t}^{\text{F}}, the results imply that the pricing of a UE is sensitive to its available computing power. To incentive the UEs with higher fk,texsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} (i.e. lower-level of available computing power) to engage in an FL task, the MO has to pay a higher price for the resource usage.

Next, we show the performance of the proposed TLA-GTS, i.e., Algorithm 2 on a real FL task. The task is to classify handwritten digits using the MNIST dataset [20]. The distribution of the dataset over the UEs are balanced but non-i.i.d, and the training model is a 2-layer deep neural networks (DNN), consisting of one flatten layer, two fully-connected layers with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation and a log-softmax output layer. For each ordered model accuracy {.65, .7, .75, .8}, 100 experiments (game cycles) were performed. Fig. 3 shows the empirical cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the 100 experiments. One can see that the TLA-GTS can effectively motivate the autonomous UEs to help the MO achieve the accuracy goal of the FL task.

Finally, we verify the superiority of TLA-GTS by comparing with other two schemes. Given that most of the related works do not consider the user’s EX-task load, the first scheme to be compared is the game-theoretic scheme without the task-load-aware mechanism. It is termed as the pure-GTS, which still uses the proposed game framework, but the energy cost of a UE does not consider the impact of its EX-task load, i.e., E~k,tF=νk​(fk)2​Ttrnsuperscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑘𝑡Fsubscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘2superscript𝑇trn\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}=\nu_{k}\left(f_{k}\right)^{2}T^{\text{trn}} in eq. (7). Another scheme to be compared is the independent linear pricing strategy (ILPS), in which, each UE prices the MO independently using a linear pricing strategy based on its available resources, regardless of the pricing of other UEs. For each ordered model accuracy, the profits of the UEs using the different schemes are shown in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4, one can see that both the game-theoretic schemes TLA-GTS and pure-GTS outperform the ILPS as they bring higher profits for each of the UEs. This is because the game-theoretic schemes can price the resources of UEs based on their energy cost and the pricing of other UEs in the same training session. Furthermore, one can also note that the TLA-GTS outperforms the pure-GTS in all cases. This is because that the energy cost of a UE in an FL task depends not only on the FL-task load but also on the EX-task load, which causes the UEs to produce the same amount of CPU cycles but consume different amount of energy. Hence, the TLA-GTS brings the UEs the highest profits in the game.

VI Conclusion

This paper has proposed a game theoretic approach to motivate UEs to participate in FL and the NE of the game has been obtained by a distributed iterative algorithm. Simulation results have verified the effectiveness of the proposed approaches.
